descriptionSet.description: The image by Oriental Calender Manufacturing Company, Calcutta shows Krishna standing on a lotus flower, holding aloft the Indian flag in his right hand and a spool of thread in his left hand that is attached to Gandhi's spinning wheel. He has a garland around his neck, is wearing a cape and a crown with a peacock feather on it. Jawaharlal Nehru and Gandhi sit on the ground, by Krishna's feet. Krishna is strewing flowers over Gandhi's head from his left hand. Nehru holds the flag pole of the Indian flag and has a book by his side. Trees and the moon can be seen in the background. The ground beneath them is depicted in the shape of India.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

titleSet.title: Mahatma Gandhi, Jawaharlal Nehru and Lord Krishna
जवाहिर लाल नेहरू , गान्धी जी

hra:item.hra:value: description-en: The image by Oriental Calender Manufacturing Company, Calcutta shows Krishna standing on a lotus flower, holding aloft the Indian flag in his right hand and a spool of thread in his left hand that is attached to Gandhi's spinning wheel. He has a garland around his neck, is wearing a cape and a crown with a peacock feather on it. Jawaharlal Nehru and Gandhi sit on the ground, by Krishna's feet. Krishna is strewing flowers over Gandhi's head from his left hand. Nehru holds the flag pole of the Indian flag and has a book by his side. Trees and the moon can be seen in the background. The ground beneath them is depicted in the shape of India. (gs/sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Perhaps the deepest performative productivity is achieved through viewers/consumers’ interventions by “modes of image customization – such as the application of glitter or zari (brocade) or the adhesion of paper surrounds or plastic flowers – [these] are also corpothetic extensions that move the image closer to the devotee, transforming the ostensible representation or window into a surface deeply inscribed…” (Sandria B. Freitag)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: It is clear from the extant examples that certain kinds of images lend themselves best to such embellishment, performed itself as an act of devotion. These types of images enable a customization to fit the needs and devotional aspirations of the consumer, and are, by and large, images of gods (whether in advertisements or not) and subjects related to nationalism or equivalent imagery for group identity. The “passionate devotionalism” we have recognized before is played out in its most tangible form here. (Sandria B. Freitag)(gs)
related literature: Braudel, Fernand 1981. "The Structures of Everyday Life". London: Collins. (gs)
related literature: de Certeau, Michel 1984. "The Practices of Everyday Life" . Berkeley: University of California Press. (gs)
